{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3352114,"name":"Arjan","username":"blanck","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/848f3c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:07:48.014Z","cooked":"

Attention best CADers and Designers on Chief Delphi if you had to learn CAD and design principles again from scratch how would you do it?

I am trying to learn over the summer and during the next off-season and am hoping for some tips, advice and or links?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:07:48.014Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":335,"reads":368,"readers_count":367,"score":1758.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461269,"topic_slug":"learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch","display_username":"Arjan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch/461269/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3352139,"name":null,"username":"2930notjorde","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/2930notjorde/{size}/246278_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:38:46.849Z","cooked":"

Step one: Find a good mentor, ideally one who has been doing FRC design for 5+ years and knows what to look for game-to-game. A solid design mentor base is how you get design knowledge that spans ‘generations’ of FRC students.

Step 2 is a bit more team dependent. Do you have the resources (aforementioned mentors, committed 3+ year tenure design students, sufficient technology, etc.) to assemble your own training course tailored specifically to your team? For most teams, the answer is no. If you can, great! A personalized course will always be the best option. But otherwise…

Courses from other teams! My personal favorite is Robochargers 3005’s course, which can be found here. IIRC, 3847 Spectrum also has some resources for this sort of thing. Look around! Many teams have done their own courses, and published them to public spaces such as here.

Step three is the one that’s arguably the most resource dependent. Can you build (machining and assembly included) an off-season bot every year? This could be for the ‘current’ game, or even a previous one… all the documentation is available on FIRST’s website. If you can, then this is the #1 way kids can learn design in a calm, non-build season environment. And with the fabrication and assembly process, they can also figure out what a ‘good’ design is from those two standpoints as well.

Good luck on your building-skills-to-build-robots journey!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:38:46.849Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":367,"readers_count":366,"score":208.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461269,"topic_slug":"learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://onshape4frc.com/robochargers-curriculum#week1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 3005 RoboChargers Onshape CAD Class | Onshape4FRC","clicks":105},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/can-mechanical-design-be-learned/461442/20","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Can Mechanical Design be learned?","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57739,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2930 Alumnus; Big Sky Robotics Ri3D Club President"},"post_url":"/t/learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch/461269/2","custom_user_title":"2930 Alumnus; Big Sky Robotics Ri3D Club President","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352149,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:57:56.733Z","cooked":"

I think @howlongismyname has a bit of a community going for this one. It might help you out. (maybe shoot him a dm)

On a more objective note note though, here are my tips

  1. Use Onshape.
  • Familiarize yourself with the sketching and part design tools (but especially sketching, so much in FRC is just plates). Onshape has some good tutorials for this.
  • Install MkCad and the featurescripts from onshape4frc.com
  1. Learn the FRC workflow.
  • It’s all about “master sketches” - simplified side profiles that drive the geometry of different subsystems and models on the robot. I did a presentation on this here, there are also many other ones people have made that are great
  • Learn about how to split up your documents, part studios and assemblies in a way that makes sense (in the context of FRC) to keep everything organized
  1. Practice subsystem design
  • This is when you’ll start to learn about different COTS parts and how to design on top of your sketches
  • A great place to start is cloning existing mechanisms, based on pictures or BTB interviews
  • Get experienced designers (there’s really no shortage) to do design review as you do these
  1. Make a run at a full robot
  • Pick a cadathon game, make a mastersketch, and try your hand at integrating everything
  • Don’t sweat it if it doesn’t work out on the first try!

FRC design is something that’s pretty hard to learn because doing it well requires a very specific workflow combined with knowledge of various obscure COTS parts.

There’s no textbook for doing it, so make sure to leverage the community to hone your design skills at every step of your journey.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:59:46.191Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":183.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":461269,"topic_slug":"learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch","display_username":"Vaughn Khouri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/strategic-design-workflows-in-onshape-presentation/446487","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Strategic Design Workflows in Onshape Presentation","clicks":26},{"url":"http://onshape4frc.com","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Home | Onshape4FRC","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch/461269/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352167,"name":"Aarav","username":"Aarsenic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aarsenic/{size}/178965_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T04:25:28.892Z","cooked":"

Echoing everything here, as much as I dislike Onshape for almost everything else, it’s unmatched in terms of use in FRC. The two things I wish I learned first would have been how to master sketch and how to integrate COTS products effectively, and there’s really no better way than finding a previous game you find interesting and designing a brand new robot as if it were to be built today. I realize I might be dating myself with this but the way I got good at FRC CAD was just grinding out robot ideas for previous games during online school. The learning curve is somewhat steep but there’s so many resources out there to learn from. Some personal favorites are all of the presentations 1678 does at CCC and Anands presentation at WRRF, which I believe can all be found online

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T04:25:28.892Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":110.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461269,"topic_slug":"learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch","display_username":"Aarav","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52319,"username":"CyberClone","name":"Vaughn Khouri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55203,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Bay Area Boomer"},"post_url":"/t/learning-cad-and-robotics-design-again-from-scratch/461269/4","custom_user_title":"Bay Area Boomer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352168,"name":"Pizzatc","username":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T04:27:45.520Z","cooked":"

I’m writing this post under the assumption you remember like the basic tools of how to use CAD like lines, rectangles, patterns, etc.

As mentioned in some of the other posts I would pick a game and design a robot for that years game, for learning purposes I would recommend either 2016 or 2022.

Start with a master sketch to capture the general geometry of the robot should include the intake, climbers, shooter, hopper, etc.

From there I would create overlapping sketches for each subsystem and then from there you extrude the parts you need for each subsystem.

From there I would assemble all the parts in a unique assembly subsystem file before bringing them all together into a master assembly file which should be the complete robot.

If you don’t remember how to design the subsystems I would look for very simple robots and analyze how their subsystems work, in particular for the 2022 game 1678 had a very simple hopper and intake design so I would look for simple designs like theirs.
